awd_titl_txt: Classical, Motivic and Equivariant Stable Homotopy Groups of Spheres.
awd_abstract_narration:
Topology is a subject of mathematics that studies the shapes of spaces and interactions among them. A fundamental problem in topology is the classification problem of topological spaces and maps among them. Among all spaces, the spheres are of central importance, and we can classify them up to continuous deformation by a single number - the dimension. A one dimensional sphere, which we usually call a circle, is something that we can draw on a piece of paper, and can be described by the solutions of the familiar equation for a circle. A two dimensional sphere is something we can visualize in three dimensional space, such as the surface of a basketball, and can be described by the solutions of a similar equation. In topology, we also study higher dimensional spheres. Although these spaces cannot be visualized in three dimensions, they do exist in higher dimensions, and can also be studied. Somewhat surprisingly, maps between spheres are much harder to classify, even up to continuous deformations. This classification problem of maps between spheres is called the problem of computations of homotopy groups of spheres. This problem has been a major and active research problem since the 1950's. Much progress has been made on this problem, through all kinds of methods that have close connections to many subjects of mathematics. Recently, significant progress has been made using techniques from motivic and equivariant homotopy theory. The goal of this project is to further develop new techniques in motivic and equivariant homotopy theory, and to study this classical problem of computations of homotopy groups of spheres. Graduate students will be involved in this project.

This project concentrates on computations of stable homotopy groups of spheres, in the classical, motivic and equivariant context. More specifically, the principal investigator and collaborators will continue using techniques in motivic homotopy theory over the complex numbers to push classical computations, towards the Kervaire invariant problem in dimension 126.  The principal investigator and collaborators will extend the Chow t-structure technique defined over the complex numbers to other base fields, and study motivic stable homotopy groups of spheres over these base fields. Moreover, the PI will study with collaborators the New Doomsday Conjecture in Adams filtration 3, and use equivariant techniques to study homotopy groups of Hill-Hopkins-Ravenel type spectra.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The P.I. has successfully completed a variety of research projects on the proposed computations of stable homotopy groups of spheres, in the classical, motivic and equivariant context.

 

In the classical context, the PI and collaborators have extended their computations into a significantly larger range using various methods, including but not limited to HF2-synthetic methods, C-motivic methods, and computer-assisted techniques. Notably, the PI and collaborators have established the Adams differentials on the element hj3, proving an important case of the 3-line New Doomsday Conjecture. The PI and collaborators developed the Generalized Leibniz Rule and the Generalized Mahowald Trick, and have announced the resolution of the Last Kervaire Invariant Problem using these methods. In the motivic context, the PI and collaborators have defined and studied the Chow t-structure on motivic stable homotopy category over a general base field. Thef indings open the door to numerous applications in homotopy theory and algebraic geometry. In the equivariant context, the PI and collaborators have computed the reduced ring of the RO(C2)-graded stable stems, classifying all non-nilpotent maps between sphere. 

 

With the support of this NSF grant, the PI has published five papers and posted two additional papers on the arXiv, totaling 324 pages. Two of the published papers appeared in highly prestigious journals: a 137-page paper in Publications Mathématiques de l'IHÉS and a 67-page paper in Annals of Mathematics.

 

With the support of this NSF grant, the PI was invited to speak at the 2022 International Congress of Mathematicians (ICM), the largest conference in the field of mathematics, held every four years and organized by the International Mathematical Union (IMU). Being invited to speak at the ICM is often regarded as "the equivalent of an induction to a hall of fame."

 

Additionally, in 2023, the PI was named a Fellow of the American Mathematical Society. The PI also received the K-Theory Prize, awarded once every four years by the K-Theory Foundation to mathematicians aged 35 or younger. Furthermore, the PI won the Frontiers of Science Award in both 2023 and 2024, granted by the International Congress for Basic Science, and the ICCM Best Paper Award in 2023, presented by the International Consortium of Chinese Mathematicians.

 

With the support of this NSF grant, the PI delivered 10 conference talks, 11 colloquium talks, and 5 seminar talks related to NSF-supported research.

 

The PI is currently advising 9 graduate students at UCSD. This grant has provided financial support for these students to attend domestic and international conferences as well as summer and winter schools.

 

The PI also co-organized the UCSD topology seminar, hosting over 40 external speakers for in-person talks. More than one-third of the speakers were women, and over 85% were early-career mathematicians. These talks received partial support from this NSF grant.

 

The PI co-organized three conferences and four summer schools over the past three years. Additionally, the PI serves on the editorial boards of Peking Mathematical Journal and Mathematische Zeitschrift, acts as a referee for numerous journals, and participates in various committees at UCSD.
